courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: FinTech Regulation and Legal Policy
courses.description: This course examines the legal and regulatory aspects of Fintech, particularly in the context of Hong Kong and Mainland China, to set the foundation for a practical understanding of the legal environment in which Fintech develops and evolves. The topics covered in this course include, amongst others, the general regulatory framework for the financial markets, the specific policy for Fintech, the regulatory approach towards Fintech, equity crowdfunding regime, P2P Lending rules, robot advisory services, electronic and alternative payment systems, digital currency, program trading, contract law basics and Regtech. Given the nature of the course, a comparative approach will be adopted to examining the topics covered. The course is essential for students intending to pursue a career in the Fintech industry.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: At its completion, the students should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of FinTech regulation and legal policy particularly in the context of Hong Kong and Mainland China, identify and analyze the legal issues that typically arise in the subject area, evaluate legal rules in this area from a comparative perspective.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Optimization Methods
courses.description: This course introduces the essentials of optimization methods, including models, solution methods, and programming techniques. Topics cover linear programming, integer linear programming, nonlinear programming, and convex programming. It will highlight applications of these methods in Fintech, such as asset allocation, portfolio management, and data analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR2520 or ESTR3500 or SEEM2420 or SEEM3440
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students should
1. Have fundamental knowledge of the art of modeling problems arising from FinTech with linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming.
2. Be familiar with solution methods for solving linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming.
3. Be able to solve linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming with the assistance of computer.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces the essentials of optimization methods, including models, solution methods, and programming techniques. Topics cover linear programming, integer linear programming, nonlinear programming, and convex programming. It will highlight applications of these methods in Fintech, such as asset allocation, portfolio management, and data analysis.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Financial Innovation and Structured Products
courses.description: The course of Financial Innovation and Structured Products provides a quantitative introduction to derivative markets. In it, we will focus on (i) the fundamental mechanics of futures, swaps and option markets, (ii) risk neutral evaluation theory of asset pricing, (iii) numerical procedures related to derivatives evaluation and risk managements, (iv) the principle of financial engineering and structured product design and their applications, and (v) financial crisis and regulation.

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to financial infrastructures. Topics include trading venues and platforms, securities settlement systems, payment systems, system links that facilitate cross-border transactions, central counterparties and clearance, cybersecurity infrastructure for financial services industry, infrastructure-related systemic risk and its impact on monetary and financial stability.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Advanced Database Technologies
courses.description: To support high-speed online payments, one important issue is efficiency and another important issue is reliability for millions of payments to be transferred among accounts. This course introduces the advanced topics in database systems. The topics include query processing and optimization, transaction management, concurrency control, recovery systems, parallel databases, and distributed database systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: SEEM3550
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. Conduct data analysis using query processing techniques over a large amount of data.
2. Achieve high efficiency by using advanced parallel and distributed querying processing techniques.
3. Build reliable systems to ensure all processing tasks are correct based on transaction processing, concurrency control.
4. Maintain a heavy system by understanding how to recovery from possible systems failures

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Behavioral Analytics
courses.description: Behavioral analytics is a recent advancement that reveals customer behaviors. In this course, we will focus on (i) how to use optimization techniques to design survey questions and to collect data that are relevant to customer behaviors, (ii) theories of customer behaviors, especially those under risk, (iii) how to use data mining techniques to reveal customer behaviors, and (iv) psychological biases in customer behaviors and their impact on financial and business decisions.

courses.learning_outcomes: At its completion, the students should be able to apply basic tools of behavioral analytics to reveal investor and customer behaviors and apply them to financial and business decisions.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Data Mining for FinTech
courses.description: This course introduces key techniques on data mining, including data preprocessing, classification, association rule mining, and clustering and outlier detection. Applications of these techniques in financial market data will be discussed with hands-on practice on data mining packages.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. Perform data analysis with a data mining approach which includes data preprocessing, data integration, data mining, result evaluation and presentation.
2. Formulate a real task into a data mining problem and choose an appropriate method as the solution, according to problem characteristics, data distribution, and constraints etc.
3. Evaluate the mining results and present them, able to interactively tune the mining process based on users’ feedback.
4. Apply data mining to applications in financial technology domains and help managerial decision making.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces key techniques on data mining, including data preprocessing, classification, association rule mining, and clustering and outlier detection. Applications of these techniques in financial market data will be discussed with hands-on practice on data mining packages.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Financial Informatics
courses.description: This course introduces basic concepts, models, techniques, and applications on financial data analytics. Topics include processing and analytical techniques for data streams; processing and searching high-dimensional data; big graph analysis; Web mining; recommendation systems for Web applications. The applications may involve financial data processing and analysis, time series, portfolio management, social networks, recommender systems, and so on.

1. Understand the key issues on big data processing and analytics.
2. Acquire fundamental techniques and scalable algorithms in big data analytics, and apply software tools for big data analytics.
3. Achieve adequate perspectives of big data analytics in financial technology and services, social networking, etc.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Internet Finance
courses.description: This course provides students with the fundamentals in the operations and management of Internet finance. It will cover overall applications of Internet-based technologies such as mobile payments, social network, search engines, cloud computing, and big data on the financial sector. Specific topics include third-party payments, Internet currency, P2P lending, crowdfunding, and the use of big data in financial services. The course adopts case studies as the major means of teaching and learning.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Natural Language Processing for FinTech
courses.description: The course aims at equipping students with an overview of latest natural language processing (NLP) technologies that have been increasingly adopted in finance sector. The course will introduce basic concepts of NLP and the advanced developments based on machine learning, especially deep learning. The topics of word representations, sequence modeling, large language models, and conversational AI will be further explored. Based on the introduced foundation in NLP, multiple financial applications will be introduced to illustrate how NLP techniques, e.g., text mining, sentiment analysis, conversational AI and large language models, can increase productivity in various scenarios, including general financial data processing practice and specific RegTech and InsurTech use cases. Students will have ample opportunities to apply the learned techniques in hands-on implementation on course projects.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Advanced Financial Infrastructure
courses.description: This course provides an advanced examination of financial infrastructures, which include trading venues and platforms, securities settlement systems, payment systems, cross-border transactions interlinks, central counterparties and clearance, cybersecurity, and systemic risks. It requires students to undertake project work with a view to make concrete their understanding of the underlying technologies enabling Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure. The student projects will be required to explore the implications of new financial services technology, in particular, the licensing prerequisites, regulatory controls and supervision such new services necessitate. Students will have to form groups and select a particular infrastructure area, e.g. electronic payments or lending, and conduct a deep analysis of its operations, and thereby creating new/enhanced service propositions. It is intended that project teams will be able to create prototype solutions through collaborating with, for example, the Hong Kong and Science Technology Park (HKSTP), Cyberport, ASTRI, or other CUHK labs. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired advanced understanding of components of financial infrastructure, and its significance in the financial services sector.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Recap and overview of financial infrastructure
Week 2: Payment systems and components
Week 3: Clearing systems and components
Week 4: Securities systems and components
Week 5: Interim project presentations (project groups)
Week 6: Distributed ledger technology and its possible usage
Week 7: Digital identify and know your customer
Week 8: Guest lecture: innovation in financial infrastructure
Week 9: Control environment and systemic risk
Week 10: Cyber security
Week 11: Discussions on Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre
Week 12: Final project presentations (project groups) (external judges from industry to be invited)

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Applied Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies

meetings.instructor:
Miss TAM Chui Yuk, 
Professor IEONG Sze Chung Ricci

courses.description: The course introduces the basic underlying cryptographic concepts and technologies of blockchain as a method of securing distributed ledgers in all digital transactions. The significances of trust, anonymity and consensus mechanisms are discussed. The course also further explains the application of blockchain to cryptocurrencies and smart contracts. Examples of public and private blockchains are discussed with emphasis on the applications of blockchain in Finance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology;Exclusion: CSCI5590 or IERG5590
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 : Introduction. Basics of Cryptography and Cyber-Security
Week 2 : Public/Private Keys, Hash Functions, & Application of Cryptographic Tools to Online Banking
Week 3 : Basics of Blockchain, Distributed Ledger Technology, Trust, Anonymity
Week 4 : Types of Blockchain: Public vs Private, Permissioned vs Permissionless, Application of Cryptography to Blockchain
Week 5 : Blockchain Consensus: Byzantine General’s Problem, Transactions, Mining,

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Quantitative and Algorithmic Trading
courses.description: The industry landscape of investment, trading, and risk management has been revolutionized by computing technologies, data science, and financial engineering. To progress in tandem with the changes in the industry, the topics covered in this course leverage on the recent developments in portfolio theory, empirical finance, and quantitative and algorithmic trading. In addition to mathematical modeling, an important part of this course is the practical aspect: computational implementations with statistical tests. Given that implementation and test procedures are involved, this quantitative finance course is algorithmic and hands-on in nature.

Week 8: Factor investments and Smart Beta

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Financial Technology Internship
courses.description: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the financial technology profession. To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must (a) attend regulatory workshop provided by such regulatory authorities as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Securities & Futures Commission, and Insurance Authority, and (b) attach to a company in a financial technology related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company. There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor. At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship. The student’s grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies. Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.Students are recommended to seek the Professor-in-Charge's comment on potential internship opportunities before enrolling in the course.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Elements of RegTech for the Financial Market
courses.description: This course introduces students to a dynamic financial landscape, where safeguarding market fairness, efficiency, and security is more important than ever. With financial regulations now empowered by technologies like AI, machine learning, and advanced data analytics, this course examines how regulatory frameworks adapt to monitor trading, detect abuses, and enforce compliance in real-time. Expert speakers from the fields of information technology, finance, and law provide firsthand insights into both foundational and cutting-edge RegTech. Students will gain not only essential skills in regulatory frameworks but also hands-on training in presentation, interview, and job-readiness skills. This comprehensive experience is designed to launch students into impactful roles in the evolving FinTech and RegTech sectors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to
1. Understand Core Financial and Regulatory Principles: Equip students with a strong foundation in financial markets and the regulatory frameworks that ensure market safety, fairness, and efficiency, emphasizing their practical application in today’s global economy.
2. Gain Proficiency in Digital Asset and Blockchain Technologies: Provide students with the technical knowledge needed to navigate digital assets, blockchain, and tokenized finance, including the legal and compliance aspects of cryptocurrencies and decentralized finance.
3. Develop Practical Skills in Compliance and Risk Management: Teach students how to apply RegTech tools and techniques to real-world compliance challenges, focusing on AML/KYC, transaction monitoring, and cybersecurity within the financial and Web3 ecosystems.
4. Refine Professional Communication and Presentation Skills: Foster essential skills for clear and effective communication with legal and financial professionals, including techniques for presenting complex information, managing client relationships, and delivering persuasive presentations.
5. Cultivate Job-Ready Skills in Interviewing, Networking, and Career Planning: Prepare students for careers in finance and RegTech with hands-on training in interviewing, resume-building, and professional networking, ensuring they can stand out in competitive roles.
6. Engage with Industry Leaders and Current Market Trends: Through guest speakers and interactive discussions, students will gain insights from industry experts on the latest trends in FinTech, RegTech, and digital finance, building a robust understanding of where the industry is headed.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to Course / Legal Systems / Intellectual Property Rights
Week 2: Financial Markets 101 – Finance, Technology and the Regulator – Foundational Class
Week 3: Compliant Data - Fixed Income Valuation
Week 4: Compliant Data - Rapid development of data and technology in the sustainable finance space
Week 5: Digital assets 101 – Background, Developments, and the Regulatory Approach - Foundational Class
Week 6: Digital assets – Regulatory approach to stablecoins and beyond
Week 7: Digital assets – Digital Money, e-HKD and the regulator
Week 8: Digital assets – Forensic analysis in digital assets
Week 9: RegTech in Web3 - how a virtual insurer underwrites Web3 risks using GenAI
Week 10: RegTech - How to talk to a lawyer
Week 11: Navigating the Quantum Frontier: Blockchains, Post-Quantum Cryptography, and the Future of Digital Assets
Week 12: Final presentation
Week 13: Final exam

courses.title: Topics in Financial Technology Innovations

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
meetings.instructor:
Professor LO Ting Hong, 
Professor LO Wai Shun

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the views of global, and in particular China and HK FinTech innovation landscape, including virtual banking and other business model innovation, associated opportunities and challenges. It covers topics including digital lending, digital payment, big data analysis application, FinTech partnership & incubation, Open API, digital product propositions, organizational design to support innovation. This is relevant for students who are interested to work in innovation-related departments in traditional institutions, FinTechs or intend to initiate a start-up. The course also covers the latest development in financial technology innovations and offers case studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1: What is FinTech innovation?
• Definition of innovation and impact to financial industry
• Background on global FinTech trend and various vertical segments
• Design-led thinking approach and customer-oriented mindset (essence: customer journey mapping and customer experience creation)
• Difference between the West and the East
• Introduction of the course assessment framework
Lesson 2: What is virtual banking v.s. traditional banking?
• Difference between virtual banking and traditional (online) banking
• In-class discussion
• Introduction of global virtual (digital) banking market development
• Background on global virtual banking landscape
Lesson 3: Is virtual banking a FinTech?
• Introduction of virtual banking product offerings and value proposition
• Case study of virtual banking: Monzo and KaokaoBank
• FinTech: unbundle v.s. rebundle
• Case study of “rebundle” FinTech: Revolut and Wealthfront
• Introduction of essay paper (project work): identify 2 FinTechs who are in the same vertical segment (1 each for the West and the East), share views on their business model innovation similarities and differences; comment if this can be applied in Hong Kong and why
Lesson 4: FinTech business model innovations – virtual banking
• Introduction of business model innovation
• Virtual banking business model archetypes
• Opportunities and challenges of virtual banking
• Case study on virtual banks (in-class discussion)
- Global : ING Direct and N26
- China: PingAn Orange Bank, Webank and Mybank
Lesson 5: Virtual banking product offering – payment and lending
• Introduction of digital payment development and impact to credit card
- Guest speaker
• Introduction of consumer finance and P2P development in China, difference with traditional bank lending
• Application of big data analytics and machine learning technology
- Guest speaker
Lesson 6: Virtual banking product offering – account and Open API
• Introduction of HK remote account opening and impact to virtual banking
- Guest speaker
• Introduction of HK Open API initiative and comparison with global practices
• Case study on Open API (in-class discussion)
- UK : Starling marketplace, HSBC Connected Money
- HK: ZhongAn, MoneyHero
• Technology risk impact arising from Open API
• Introduction of presentation (course work): identify a virtual bank that is launched in Hong Kong and analyze their business operating model, suggest plans on their iteration if you’re the management team
Lesson 7: Virtual banking - China and Hong Kong regulation landscape
• Background of HKMA 7 initiatives under “a new era of smart banking”
- Guest speaker
• Background of China virtual banking regulation and landscape
• What’s next for BATJ and traditional banks – TechFin
• Potential of Greater Bay Area for HK virtual banking development
Lesson 8: Virtual banking - technology application
• Introduction of AI, blockchain, cloud and data (ABCD)
• Application of ABCD to virtual banking
• Challenges and opportunities arising from ABCD
- Guest speaker
Lesson 9: FinTech business model innovations - others
• The rise of platforms – using technology, data and customer base to create new business model
• Case study (in-class discussion)
- China: Zhong An (insurance)
- US: Amazon, Paypal and Square (platform lending)
- Southeast Asia: Grab
• What is blockchain and its applications in different markets
- Guest speaker
Lesson 10: FinTech partnership & incubation
• FinTech: friend or foe to traditional banking
• Ecosystem and partnership – day in the life of a traditional bank
• Opportunities and challenges to FinTech incubation
- Guest speaker
Lesson 11: Organizational design to support innovation
• Start up in a traditional banking v.s. start up in a virtual banking
• Difference in strategy, decision making process and way of working
- Guest speaker
Lesson 12: Presentation

courses.title: Financial Technology Entrepreneurship
courses.description: The aim of this course is to turn innovative, creative, and inquisitive FinTech students into entrepreneurs through multi-disciplinary, and project-based learning. The course covers topics in disruptive innovation and business models, human centered and design-driven innovation, business plan formulation, start-up pitch, how technology spur entrepreneurship, fundraising, growth, acquisition and IPO, making critical decisions during the journey, in order to equip participants to become entrepreneurs in the FinTech world. courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Data Analytics for Financial Technology
courses.description: The aim of this course is to equip students with essential data analytics techniques for problems in financial technology. Topics covered by this course include linear and general regression, classification techniques such as logistic regression and discriminant analysis, decision trees, support vector machines, principal component analysis, clustering methods, time series models, resampling methods and deep learning models. Various applications in asset management, risk management, asset pricing and financial prediction will be used to illustrate the methods throughout this course. Students also learn how to implement these methods in the popular data analytics software R to analyze financial data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology;Exclusion: CSCI5150
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to data-driven problems in financial technology and review of probability
Week 2: Linear regression: least squares, maximum likelihood estimation, analysis of variance, applications in exploring relationship among some financial variables
Week 3: Linear regression: trouble-shooting techniques, model selection criteria, applications in estimating factor-based asset price models
Week 4: Lasso regression and its applications in factor selection for financial problems, nonlinear regression with applications in yield curve construction
Week 5: Classification techniques: logistic regression, discriminant analysis, applications in credit risk analysis
Week 6: Decision trees: classification trees, regression trees, random forests, applications in credit risk analysis and financial time series forecasting
Week 7: Support vector machines: classifiers, applications in credit risk analysis and financial time series forecasting
Week 8: Principal component analysis with applications in the analysis of yield curve changes, clustering methods (K-means and hierarchical clustering) with applications in stock clustering analysis
Week 9: Time series models: ARIMA models and its applications in modelling and forecasting financial time series
Week 10: Time series models: GARCH models and its applications in modelling and forecasting financial time series
Week 11: Resampling methods: bootstrap, applications in estimation of risk measures
Week 12: Deep learning: commonly used neural network structures, applications in default prediction and price prediction

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Intelligent Automation - Robotic Process Automation (RPA) & Artificial Intelligence (AI)
courses.description: Intelligent Automation (IA) is software-based automation which executes business processes on behalf of knowledge workers with minimal human intervention. IA combines methods and various technologies, in particular, robotic process automation (RPA) and artificial intelligence. As the core and foundational technology of intelligent automation (IA), robotic process automation (RPA) has been described as a first step on the stairway of intelligent automation towards building digital workers. The aim of this course is to provide learners comprehensive coverage of intelligent automation – including RPA development skills and AI fundamentals– in the context of financial services. This course will build the capabilities of students to an advanced level and will enable participants to actively engage in the full lifecycle of “bot” development from assessment of automation opportunities through the building/deployment of functional automations. The course also introduces students to the latest industry developments in low-code artificial intelligence providing students with less technical backgrounds an opportunity to learn the skills to automate business processes without a need of a computer science background.Course participants are expected to:1. Gain a clear understanding of the intelligent automation (RPA + AI) industry and benefits and understand the limits and constraints of process automation.2. Learn about the role of business analysis in the context of process automation implementation including: (a) how to conduct an automation opportunity assessment; (b) how to map the requirements and deliverables of a process automation project; (c) best practices during the Process Deep Dive stage including ways of compiling comprehensive process-related documentation; (d) testing strategies for an process automation solution; (e) how to conduct trainings and create a User Manual during Go-Live preparations; and (f) how to manage changes throughout the entire process automation development process. 3. Understand the delivery methodology of process automation project/program management including: (a) steps of a process automation implementation, (b) choosing processes suitable for automation, (c) driving/managing process automation projects, and (d) raising intelligent automation awareness throughout an organization.4. Obtain a solid grasp of the technical skills required to create software robots. 5. Be able to build and deploy software robots to automate a variety of manual tasks/process encountered in financial operations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Each week: 1.5 hr lecture + 1.5 hr practical, “hands-on” lab.
Week 01: (LEC) Introduction to Intelligent Automation | (Lab) Getting started: IA Tools Overview & Community + Support Platform, IDE setup |(Lab) Overview
Week 02: (LEC) Components Technologies & Basic Skills | (Lab) Editing and Debugging UI Flows + Variables [+ Lists], UI Elements & Images |(Lab) How to use low-code AI models
Week 03: (LEC) Tool Assessment & Selection | (Lab) Basic Structure Elements and Flow Control [conditional actions (if and Loop)] |(Lab)Pre-built Models: Business card reader, Text recognition, Receipt processing
Week 04: (LEC) Automation Opportunity Identification (AOA) | (Lab) Actions for UI Automation + Automating Standard Business (Biz) Apps (1of4) – [Excel automation] |(Lab) Pre-built Models: Invoice process, ID read, Key phrase extraction
Week 05: (LEC) AOA 2.0 – automating process discovery | (Lab)Automating Standard Biz Apps (2of4) – Application automation (Calculator and MS Word)|(Lab)Pre-built Models: Language detection, Sentiment analysis, Text translation
Week 06: (LEC) Process Automation & Process Excellence | (Lab) Automating Standard Biz Apps (3of4) – Outlook email and Browser automation|(Lab)Pre-built Models: Text generation, Category classification, Image Description
Week 07: (LEC) Bot Development with Agile/Scrum | (Lab) Automating Standard Biz Apps (4of4) – Web Scraping|(Lab)Custom models: Doc processing, Category classification , Entity extraction
Week 08: (LEC) Automation Center of Excellence (CoE) | (Lab)Desktop & Workstation Automation – [File handling]|(Lab)Custom models: Prediction, Object detection
Week 09: (LEC) Globalization of Intelligent Automation: China perspectives | (Lab) PDF data extraction |(Lab)Integration of low-code Generative AI Solutions
Week 10: (LEC) AI Fundamentals for Executives (“AI 101”) | (Lab) Exception Handling|(Lab)Introduction to low-code Agentic Workflows
Week 11: (LEC) Future Prospects (more AI, citizen dev & beyond…) | (Lab) E2E project: Process Automation Challenge
Development Best Practices
Week 12: Project Presentations + 15min Student Course Evaluation Period + “Last Minute Course Q&A” / Course Review
Week 13: FINAL EXAM

courses.description: This course will introduce pricing models and algorithms in managing the risks and making decisions regarding the trading and analysis of financial assets. Main areas that will be covered include, but not limited to: (i) Models for asset allocation; (ii) Derivative models and products; (iii) Practical applications of financial modelling. Assignments will be set up to help students develop an intuitive understanding of how these models can be implemented.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology; Not for students who have taken CMSC5718 or SEEM5820
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces some basic concepts in computational finance and their application in real markets. Topics include modern portfolio theory, asset allocation models, utility functions, evaluation of portfolio performance, stochastic models for derivative pricing and trading. Throughout the course, examples from Asian markets will be used in illustrating the concepts.
Week 01: Introduction; Modern Portfolio Theory (part I)
Week 02: Modern Portfolio Theory (part II)
Week 03: Equilibrium in Capital Markets: CAPM and APT
Week 04: Practical models in asset allocation: Black-Litterman and Risk Parity
Week 05: Derivative market and instruments
Week 06: Basic stochastic models and Monte Carlo simulations
Week 07: Derivative product analysis (part I)
Week 08: Derivative product analysis (part II)
Week 09: Practical models in asset allocation: Indexing techniques and ESG investing
Week 10: Portfolio evaluation and risk measures
Week 11: Option volatility and hedging
Week 12: Quantitative trading strategies involving derivatives
Week 13: Examination

courses.subject: FTEC

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a practical and management level understanding of how technology is and could be used and applied to the management, growth and development of wealth management business in Hong Kong / Mainland as well as Asia and other parts of the world. Key topics to be discussed include the regulatory framework for wealth management industry, a review of the relationship between macro-economic cycle and wealth management product development and product shelf management strategies, roles and responsibilities of the various players within the wealth management industry value chain to fulfill various stages of individual customers’ financial needs, wealth management business proposition including sales and marketing strategies, and the technology and operational infrastructure required to support and to enhance the business process and to deliver exceptional customer experience.

courses.title: Green FinTech

meetings.instructor:
Miss TAM Chui Yuk, 
Mr. HUNG Man Ching

courses.description: This course focuses on the intersection of green finance and financial technology, equipping students with the knowledge and skills to drive innovation in the green fintech space. It covers a range of topics, from renewable energy finance to sustainable infrastructure, carbon markets, and ESG data management, all within the context of fintech-enabled solutions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students should be able to explain the key technology components, enablers and success factors for a green fintech business, and for those students who are interested in developing further academic study and research, or in preparing them to take up fintech job roles.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Green Fintech
- Overview of the intersection of green finance and financial technology
- Sustainability challenges and the role of fintech in enabling green finance
- Emerging trends and innovations in the green fintech landscape
2. Sustainable Finance Fundamentals
- Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria and their integration in investment decisions
- Sustainable investment strategies and their application in fintech solutions
- Measuring and reporting on sustainability performance using digital tools
3. Green Fintech for Renewable Energy
- Financing models for renewable energy projects using digital platforms
- Blockchain-based solutions for renewable energy trading and peer-to-peer transactions
- AI-powered predictive analytics for optimizing renewable energy investments
4. Green Fintech for Sustainable Infrastructure
- Fintech-enabled financing for green buildings, transportation, and water/waste management
- Integrating IoT and sensor data to monitor and improve infrastructure sustainability
- Crowd-funding and peer-to-peer lending for sustainable infrastructure projects
5. Fintech for Carbon Finance and Emissions Trading
- Blockchain-based platforms for carbon credit trading and offset management
- AI-driven carbon footprint tracking and emissions reporting
- Fintech solutions for carbon pricing and carbon market mechanisms
6. Green Fintech for Sustainable Agriculture and Forestry
- Fintech-enabled financing for precision agriculture and sustainable land use
- Satellite and drone-based monitoring for sustainable forestry practices
- Blockchain-powered traceability and supply chain management in the agri-food sector
7. Sustainable Finance Taxonomies and Standards in Fintech
- Integrating green finance taxonomies and certification schemes in fintech applications
- Developing fintech-enabled tools for sustainability data collection and analysis
- Challenges and opportunities in harmonizing global sustainable finance standards
8. Fintech for Mobilizing Green Finance
- Crowdfunding, peer-to-peer lending, and digital investment platforms for green projects
- Fintech-enabled green bond issuance and trading
- Innovative fintech models for blended finance and de-risking green investments
9. ESG Data Management and Reporting in Fintech
- Leveraging big data, AI, and machine learning for ESG data collection and analysis
- Fintech solutions for streamlining ESG disclosure and reporting
- Addressing data quality, privacy, and security challenges in green fintech
10. Sustainable Finance Risk Management and Compliance
- Fintech-powered risk assessment and underwriting for green investments
- Regulatory and compliance considerations in green fintech development
- Cybersecurity and ethical concerns in sustainable finance technology
11. Fintech for Sustainable Finance Education and Engagement
- Gamification and digital learning tools for green finance literacy
- Fintech-enabled platforms for sustainable investment decision-making
- Engaging retail investors and communities in green finance through fintech
12. Green Fintech Innovation and Entrepreneurship
- Incubating and accelerating green fintech startups and ventures
- Collaborative innovation between traditional finance and fintech firms
- Emerging business models and revenue streams in the green fintech ecosystem
13. Future Trends in Green Fintech
- Innovations in green finance.
- Emerging trends and technologies.
- The future landscape of green finance.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Decentralized Finance

meetings.instructor:
Miss TAM Chui Yuk, 
Professor LAU Wing Cheong

courses.description: This course provides a foundational introduction to Decentralized Finance (DeFi) with an aim to bridge decentralized/ distributed computing and finance. Students will learn about decentralized systems, distributed consensus, blockchains, smart contracts, and the contrast between DeFi and traditional finance. The course starts with a brief review of the notion of money, conventional banking and payment systems. It then proceeds to cover different DeFi assets including cryptocurrencies, tokens and stablecoins. Various DeFi infrastructure technologies such as Decentralized Exchanges (DEX), Automated Market Maker (AMM) protocols, Decentralized Lending/ Borrowing protocols, and Oracles are also discussed. The course concludes with decentralized governance, DeFi risk management and best practices for DeFi security. By exploring the intricacies of DeFi ecosystems, students will gain a better understanding of the opportunities, challenges, and systemic risks associated with this emerging field.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the operating principles and concepts underlying various DeFi services.
2. Explain how cryptocurrencies, tokens, and smart contracts can be used to implement different financial services.
3. Evaluate various DeFi services by analyzing their strengths, limitations, potential applications and risks.
4. Assess the potential impact of different DeFi services on the financial industry and the society.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Overview of DeFi
Week 2: Introduction to Money, Traditional Finance, Banking and Payment systems
Week 3: Blockchain Fundamentals
Week 4: Introduction to Smart Contracts
Week 5: Cryptocurrencies and Tokens
Week 6: Decentralized Exchanges (DEX) and Automated Market Maker (AMM) Protocols
Week 7: Decentralized Lending / Borrowing protocols
Week 8: Stablecoins
Week 9: Oracles
Week 10: Derivatives
Week 11: DeFi Security, Risk Management and Regulatory Issues
Week 12: Emerging trends and future directions of DeFi
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.
courses.required_readings: There is no textbook that can satisfy the needs of this course. The course contents will be organized in the form of lecture notes, as well as a list of recommended readings.

Kaihua Qin, Liyi Zhou, Yaroslav Afonin, Ludovico Lazzaretti, Arthur Gervais, “CeFi vs. DeFi - Comparing Centralized to Decentralized Finance,” 2021 Crypto Valley Conference on Blockchain Technology (CVCBT), arXiv:2106.08157.
Fabian Schär, “Decentralized Finance: On Blockchain and Smart Contract-Based Financial Markets,” Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis Review, Feb 2021.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Topics in International Fintech
courses.description: Hong Kong is “Asia’s world city” and an international financial center as well as an emerging innovation hub. Accordingly, it is important for Hong Kong’s fintech students to develop a much broader understanding of the international fintech ecosystems. This course aims to expand students’ knowledge of the fintech landscapes beyond the borders of mainland China and Hong Kong SAR perspectives. The course learning material will help students to appreciate the unique and significant difference of the Hong Kong fintech ecosystems from other international jurisdictions. Students are introduced to the latest international fintech trends and are provided with an overview of the respective ecosystems* of:(1) Africa (Sub-Saharan Africa)(2) Middle East & North Africa(3) Asia (South Asia)(4) East Asia & Pacific(5) Europe and Central Asia(6) Latin America & the Caribbean (7) North America*geographic ecosystems for the course are organized according to the World Bank analytical grouping scheme of seven (7) regions (https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/archive/2017/the-world-by-region.html)The course addresses the concept of techno-business ecosystems via a comprehensive framework including: people/firms, markets, policy/regulation, culture, finance, and infrastructure support.This course will also include a variety of C-suite level and international guest speakers to supplement lecture course material. Topics will be updated year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 01: Overview of the Int'l Fintech Competitive Landscape (HK as a "super connector to the world")
Week 02 - Week 08: Int’l Fintech Ecosystem Africa (Sub-Saharan Africa) region; Middle East & North Africa region; Asia (South Asia) region; East Asia & Pacific region; Europe and Central Asia region; Latin America & Caribbean region; North America.
Week 09: Global Trading Blocs & Collaborative Orgs within the Int’l Fintech Landscape
Week 10: Intergovernmental Regulation within the Int’l Fintech Landscape
Week 11: Future outlook of the international fintech landscape
Week 12: Presentation (Project)
Week 13: Final Exam
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students' comments and feedback concerning the teaching and learning in the course are most welcome.
1. Course questionnaire: Students are required to provide feedback on various aspects related to the teaching and learning of the course at the end of the term.
2. Individual contacts: Students are also welcome to provide feedback to the course lecturer right after each lecture, using email, direct phone call or office visits.
courses.required_readings: Instructor curated teaching materials & lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings: Instructor curated recommended reading and videos based on latest industry trends and professional practice.

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Agentic AI for Business and FinTech
courses.description: Traditional AI models can respond to prompts or execute predefined tasks impressively. Agentic AI goes beyond traditional AI by incorporating a "chaining" capability: it can take a “sequence” of actions in response to a single request, breaking down complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps or coordinating among multiple agents to achieve a common goal. Agentic AI systems have a high degree of autonomy and can act with minimal human supervision. Agentic AI could revolutionize business and financial technologies of the future. This course introduces the students to the fundamentals of agentic systems, covering reinforcement learning agents, language model agents, and multi-agent systems. We will cover applications of agentic systems in various aspects of business and fintech, including cryptocurrency/blockchain, financial analysis, portfolio management, customer service, human resources, business planning, and operations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to agentic systems, Revision on machine learning concepts and deep neural networks
Week 2: Reinforcement learning agents (theory)
Week 3: Reinforcement learning agent (applications in market simulation, etc.)
Week 4: Fundamentals of language models (transformer, tokenization, prompts)
Week 5: Language model agent capabilities (memory, reasoning)
Week 6: Language model agent capabilities (tool use, planning)
Week 7: Language model agents (applications in fintech
Week 8: Multi-agent systems (theory)
Week 9: Multi-agent systems (applications in portfolio management and business operations)
Week 10: Midterm exam (90 minutes)
Week 11: Benchmarking and performance evaluation
Week 12: Safety, alignment, and mechanistic interpretability
Week 13: Project presentation

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Financial Technology Entrepreneurship Field Trip

meetings.instructor:
Miss TAM Chui Yuk, 
Professor LO Wai Shun

courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with knowledge and experiences of entrepreneurship in real-life environment. Students will participate in a week-long field-trip (e.g. in Silicon Valley, Crypto Valley or Singapore, etc.), to visit organisations on various FinTech domains for a close-up on the operation. Course learning activities include lectures/ seminars at universities/ companies, discussions with management of start-up companies, and site visits to enterprises, etc. Through these activities, students will be able to learn practical operational knowledge and experience from FinTech entrepreneurs in close distance.Student should take part in a class group project, to present the research findings on FinTech entrepreneurship and the learning outcomes of the field trip
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to
1. Have a basic understanding of FinTech developments in the city/region of visit
2. Learn from the entrepreneurs on how to pursue opportunities and leverage resources within the ecosystem
3. Understand the regulatory framework of the city/region
courses.course_syllabus: 5 days of visits to various FinTech companies and regulators in a city outside of Hong Kong

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: AI Applications in FinTech
courses.description: Characteristics of financial data, patterns, and models, time-series representation and prediction. Limitations of classical system identification for prediction problems. Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) in AI: Recurrent and feedforward neural networks and their learning architectures: matrix computations and fast neural learning hardware realization. Reinforcement learning and dynamic programming. Integration of statistical techniques and neural learning, for applications in financial prediction, investment strategies and planning. Simulation of generative AI for potential applications and their evaluations. Exploring robo-advisors using generative AI with large language model (LLM) for enhancing wealth creation and investment outcomes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Financial Technology or PgD Financial Technology;Good knowledge in linear algebra, probability, and calculus and familiarity with programming languages C or Python. Some acquaintance on using MATLAB and R is advantageous
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understanding financial time series modeling and basic statistical knowledge for analysis, and estimation
2. Learning basic MATLAB/PYTHON/R programming skill for linear model estimation and identification
3. Understanding artificial neural network and learning schemes, including recurrent and feed-forward architectures, reinforcement learning and dynamic programming
4. Learning MATLAB/PYTHON/R programming skill for neural networks construction and their simulation
5. Understanding the current development of efficient hardware platforms for supporting large scale neural computation
6. Simulations of generative AI for financial prediction, investment strategies and planning
7. Exploring robo-advisors using generative AI with large language models (LLMs) for enhancing wealth creation and investment outcomes.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Basic time series models for financial data and MATLAB/PYTHON/R programming
Week 2: Linear model estimation and identification, ARX/GARCH models for prediction and volatility estimation
Week 3: Introduction to artificial neural networks (ANN): Hopfield network, Hebbian learning, Boltzmann machines and their applications
Week 4: Different architectures of neural networks and basic learning algorithms
Week 5: Non-supervisory recurrent neural networks and programming
Week 6: Supervisory feedforward backpropagation networks and programming
Week 7: Reinforcement learning and dynamic programming planning
Week 8: Application study of using ANN for financial prediction
Week 9: Application study of using ANN for investment strategies
Week 10: Current development of efficient hardware platforms for supporting large scale neural computation
Week 11: The simulation of generative AI for applications
Week 12: Application study of robo-advisors using large language models and generative AI
Week 13: Project presentations

courses.subject: FTEC
courses.title: Financial Technology Project I
courses.description: The courses, Financial Technology Project I & II, involve a significant research and/or development project under the supervision of an academic staff in any area of financial technology. Unless otherwise approved by the Professor-in-Charge, the project should involve an industrial partner with a co-supervisor from the industry. At the end of the course, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report detailing the findings and deliverables. The student’s grade will be determined by the presentation and the report.Unless otherwise approved by the Programme Director, the credits for Financial Technology Project I are recognized if and only if the student takes also Financial Technology Project II in a subsequent semester.If a student has prior industrial background and has already secured a project topic with an industrial practitioner and the agreement of an academic staff, Financial Technology Project I can be taken in the first semester of studies. Otherwise, the two project courses can be taken in any consecutive semesters, including the summer term.Students are encouraged to find industrial projects by themselves and talk to various academic staffs for project ideas before enrolling in the courses.
